description: From French vétyver (older spelling) or vétiver, from Tamil வெட்டிவேர் (veṭṭivēr).

entries.meaning: The grass Chrysopogon zizanioides ( <= Vetiveria zizanioides), which is native to India, but planted throughout the tropics for its fragrant roots and for erosion control.
examples: Two types of vetiver have been found in India – (i) flowering or seeding vetiver which grows wild in North India, and (ii) non-flowering or non-seeding vetiver which is cultivated in South India.

entries.meaning: The aromatic root of the grass.
An essential oil derived from the root; the fragrance of the oil.
examples: She pressed his hand and was gone in a mist of vetiver, abruptly as the other evening.
